awd_titl_txt: Chirality-Driven Self-Assembly of Dual Catalytic Dendrimers: Application Toward One-Pot Tandem Reactions
awd_abstract_narration:
In living cells many simultaneous chemical transformations occur with no interference between the enzymes that catalyze them. To accomplish this Nature has evolved to incorporate catalyst sites within enzyme pockets or by physical separation using membranes. The successful construction of artificial analogues of such frameworks would reduce catalyst deactivation and eliminate undesirable side reactions. These are important goals in catalysis with many potential practical applications. With funding from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Dr. Moteki of the University of Missouri Kansas City is developing synthetic materials possessing multiple types of incompatible catalyst sites where the sites are spatially isolated. Together with Dr. Palencia of the University of Nebraska Kearney, the catalytic efficiency and reaction scope of these catalysts are being tested. Drs. Moteki and Palencia are actively recruiting students from local high schools and community colleges, targeting underrepresented minority students, and providing them with early research experience. The research experience will increasing retention, and enhancement of underserved populations in STEM field. Summer workshops for community and small college faculty are also being conducted. Such efforts are crucial in forming new generations of young research scientists.

Tandem-catalyzed reactions have been widely recognized as one of the most efficient atom economical and environmentally friendly processes, due to minimization of waste generation. In particular, orthogonal tandem catalysis, which features two or more distinct catalysts with differing mechanisms, offers potential for higher process efficiency. Over the past few decades only a handful of successful examples have been reported primarily due to the difficulty in creating compartmented macro-structures that spatially separate incompatible catalysts. This proposal aims at building a multi-component catalytic dendrimer complex via chiral self-discrimination, which enables the in situ quantitative assembly of various multi-domain dendrimers through metal-chiral ligand interactions. This allows tuning of the microenvironment far easier than conventional covalently assembled systems, making it a more attractive system for reaction screening targeting various multi-step tandem chemical transformations. Our research team aims to understand the underlying catalyst structure-function relationship of the dual catalytic dendrimer by varying polarity as well as architectural design of each catalytic domains. In addition, the efficiency and versatility of dual catalytic dendrimers will be investigated, by using three different types of tandem reactions as models; i) substrate-selective tandem catalysis, ii) tandem reaction involving a catalytically reversible step, and iii) tandem reaction involving competitive catalytic pathways. The operational simplicity in reaction screening and the dendron preparation synthetic steps is ideal for training the next generation of synthetic chemists. Dr. Moteki and Dr. Palencia are actively engaged in outreach activity, they will host an annual workshop as means of recruiting of underserved minority students from local high schools and community colleges for summer research internship in their research groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on 1) the design/preparation of reusable multi-functional catalysts constructed through chirality-directed self-assembly and 2) the enhancement of minority research participation and the creation/execution of student-led outreach activities aimed at underserved populations.

 

The chirality-directed self-assembly enables the formation of a specific heterochiral metal-ligand

complex, enabling the designing and synthesizing of discrete nanostructured objects. The fundamental principle of this approach is the sizeable thermodynamic differentiation of heterochiral and homochiral metal-ligand complexes arising from steric interaction among substituents on chiral bis methylene bisoxazoline (BOX) ligands.

 

Among all chiral BOX derivatives prepared from commercially available amino alcohols, Ph-substituted BOX provides versatility in applications due to its ability to generate homochiral- and heterochiral Zn(II) complexes selectively. This enables the design/construction of flexible supramolecular structures with transformable frameworks.

 

The chirality-directed self-assembly was successfully applied for the in-situ preparation of various Janus dendrimers having heterochiral Zn(II) BOX complex at a focal point. Janus dendrimers can be prepared quantitatively using two alternative approaches: 1) mixing equimolar amounts of both hydrophobic/hydrophobic BOX-dendron subunits in the presence of zinc (II) acetate, or 2) mixing hydrophobic and hydrophilic dendrimers with homochiral Zn(II) BOX complexes at their focal point. In both cases, target Janus dendrimers were prepared under very mild conditions simply by mixing each subunit. Therefore, our approach applies to Janus dendrimers, which have a wide range of sensitive functional groups.

 

These investigations yielded valuable information on building supramolecular materials using chirality-directed self-assembly:

1) High selectivity in forming heterochiral Zn(II) BOX complexes regardless of the size of the attached dendron subunits, promising evidence for building versatile supramolecular structures.

2) High thermal stability of the Zn(II) BOX complex at the focal point enables the application of supramolecular catalyst in a wide range of temperatures.

3) High reversibility of the complex under relatively mild conditions (EDTA) enabling a recovery of dendron subunits without disturbing the integrity of functional groups on the supramolecular structures.

 

The characteristic advantages of our self-assembly approach led to the preparation of a recyclable/renewable/exchangeable heterogeneous catalyst system.

 

The study provides new insight on:

1) Resulting immobilized catalysts were stable in a wider range of temperatures and solvents, showing our approach's potency in a broader range of catalytic chemical transformations.

2) Catalysts loaded through self-assembly with chiral Zn(II) BOX complex can be easily removed under mild conditions using the EDTA solution, preserving the functional integration of supporting resins. As a result, our approach significantly reduces the operation cost by increasing solid support's reusability.   

3) The seamless transition from homochiral Zn(II) BOX complex to heterochiral Zn(II) BOX complex through ligand exchange led to a catalyst replacement on the supporting resin. This enables single solid support in two-step orthogonal tandem catalysis using incompatible catalysts.

 

The fund provided opportunities for the participation of i) five master’s students, ii) fifteen undergraduate students, and iii) three high school students in research held at PI’s lab. One MS student proceeded to earn PhD degree in chemistry. The most recent publications include five undergraduate students and one MS student as primary or secondary authors. Among undergraduate students, 11 (9 female) received highly competitive institutional research scholarships (SUROP/SEARCH award). In addition, two black students were selected as student representatives from the institution to present/discuss research with state lawmakers at the Missouri Capitol (Research Day @ Capitol).

Several undergraduate students initiated student-led outreach activities where they established a strong pipeline through their past instructors at high school. Participating students took the lead on content and approaches based on their background and knowledge of the local community. The strategy was highly successful as students, rather than PIs, have deep ties with instructors, students, and the local community to attract more interest in their outreach efforts.

 

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2024
Modified by: Shin Moteki

This project focused on 1) the design/preparation of reusable multi-functional catalysts constructed through chirality-directed self-assembly and 2) the enhancement of minority research participation and the creation/execution of student-led outreach activities aimed at underserved populations.





The chirality-directed self-assembly enables the formation of a specific heterochiral metal-ligand


complex, enabling the designing and synthesizing of discrete nanostructured objects. The fundamental principle of this approach is the sizeable thermodynamic differentiation of heterochiral and homochiral metal-ligand complexes arising from steric interaction among substituents on chiral bis methylene bisoxazoline (BOX) ligands.





Among all chiral BOX derivatives prepared from commercially available amino alcohols, Ph-substituted BOX provides versatility in applications due to its ability to generate homochiral- and heterochiral Zn(II) complexes selectively. This enables the design/construction of flexible supramolecular structures with transformable frameworks.

Therefore, our approach applies to Janus dendrimers, which have a wide range of sensitive functional groups.





These investigations yielded valuable information on building supramolecular materials using chirality-directed self-assembly:


1) High selectivity in forming heterochiral Zn(II) BOX complexes regardless of the size of the attached dendron subunits, promising evidence for building versatile supramolecular structures.


2) High thermal stability of the Zn(II) BOX complex at the focal point enables the application of supramolecular catalyst in a wide range of temperatures.

The characteristic advantages of our self-assembly approach led to the preparation of a recyclable/renewable/exchangeable heterogeneous catalyst system.





The study provides new insight on:

Participating students took the lead on content and approaches based on their background and knowledge of the local community.
